content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

A bottle of milk is taken out of a refrigerator and placed in a pan of hot water to be warmed. The increasing function <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> models the temperature of the milk at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="M of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in degrees Celsius (<math alttext="degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mtext>°C</mtext></mpadded></math>) and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is the number of minutes since the bottle was placed in the pan. <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of M with respect to t, equals, one fourth times, open parenthesis, 40 minus M, close parenthesis " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>40</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>M</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the temperature of the milk is <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mtext>°C</mtext></math>. It can be shown that <math alttext="M of t, is less than 40 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo><</mo><mn>40</mn></math> for all values of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.

(a) A slope field for the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of M with respect to t, equals, one fourth times, open parenthesis, 40 minus M, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>40</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>M</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is shown. Sketch the solution curve through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>0</mn></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mpadded><mn>5</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

A bottle of milk is taken out of a refrigerator and placed in a pan of hot water to be warmed. The increasing function <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> models the temperature of the milk at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="M of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in degrees Celsius (<math alttext="degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mtext>°C</mtext></mpadded></math>) and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is the number of minutes since the bottle was placed in the pan. <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of M with respect to t, equals, one fourth times, open parenthesis, 40 minus M, close parenthesis " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>40</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>M</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the temperature of the milk is <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mtext>°C</mtext></math>. It can be shown that <math alttext="M of t, is less than 40 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo><</mo><mn>40</mn></math> for all values of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.

(a) A slope field for the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of M with respect to t, equals, one fourth times, open parenthesis, 40 minus M, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>40</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>M</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is shown. Sketch the solution curve through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>0</mn></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mpadded><mn>5</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.

(b) Use the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> at <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to approximate <math alttext="M of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, the temperature of the milk at time <math alttext="t equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> minutes.

(c) Write an expression for <math alttext="the second derivative of M with respect to t " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. Use <math alttext="the second derivative of M with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></math> to determine whether the approximation from part (b) is an underestimate or an overestimate for the actual value of <math alttext="M of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Use separation of variables to find an expression for <math alttext="M of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of M with respect to t, equals, one fourth times, open parenthesis, 40 minus M, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>40</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>M</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> with initial condition <math alttext="M of 0 equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>0</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
